qas.question: What have translators tried to preserve?

answers.text: reproducing the original order of sememes

qas.question: What is it sometimes necessary to reinterpret when translating?
What is the active voice sometimes shifted to when needed?
What are the syntax characteristics of a text's source language adjusted to for a target language?
What have translators tried to get rid of?

plausible_answers.text: reproducing the original order of sememes

qas.question: What is it sometimes unnecessary to reinterpret when translating?
What is the active voice never shifted to when needed?

context: In general, translators have sought to preserve the <a0_0><b5_0>context itself<b5_0/><a0_0/> by <a1_0><b6_0>reproducing the original order of sememes<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and hence word order — when necessary, reinterpreting the actual <a2_0><b7_0>grammatical structure<b7_0/><a2_0/>, for example, by shifting from active to <a3_0><b8_0>passive<b8_0/><a3_0/> voice, or vice versa. The grammatical differences between "fixed-word-order" languages (e.g. English, French, German) and "free-word-order" languages (e.g., Greek, Latin, Polish, Russian) have been no impediment in this regard. The particular syntax (sentence-structure) characteristics of a text's source language are adjusted to the <a4_0>syntactic requirements<a4_0/> of the target language.
